#Text=Dionysius I , Metropolitan of Malankara
#Text=Mar Dionysius I , also known as Mar Thoma VI ( died 8 April 1808 ) , was the Metropolitan of the Malankara Church from 1765 until his death .

#Text=A member of the Pakalomattom family , he was a shrewd administrator who appealed to outside authorities to assert his position as the sole leader of the Malankara Church and to attempt to reunite all the Saint Thomas Christians .

#Text=Mar Thoma VI succeeded Mar Thoma V as Malankara Metropolitan in 1765 , and unlike his predecessors , who were claimed by their opponents not to have been properly ordained as bishop , he received orders from Syriac Orthodox bishops in 1772 , thus ending any controversy .

#Text=Other events of his reign include the separation of the Thozhiyoor church ( now the Malabar Independent Syrian Church ) , the arrival of English Protestant missionaries , and the first translation of the Bible from Syriac to Malayalam .
#Text=Life
#Text=The man who would be Mar Dionysius was the nephew of his predecessor as Malankara Metropolitan , Mar Thoma V , and a member of the Pakalomattom family .

#Text=In 1757 , as part of a play to assert his authority and autonomy in the Syriac Orthodox Church , Mar Thoma V consecrated his nephew as coadjutor bishop and named him his successor , in contradiction to the wishes of the Syriac Orthodox hierarchy .
#Text=Upon Mar Thoma V 's death in 1765 , the younger Pakalomattom was ordained as Metropolitan on 8 May , taking the name Mar Thoma VI . [ 1 ] [ 2 ]
#Text=As with his predecessors as Metropolitan going back to the first , Mar Thoma I , Mar Thoma VI 's critics charged that his succession , and therefor his position , was invalid .
#Text=To overcome this criticism , in 1772 Mar Thoma VI underwent a second ordination at the hands of the Syriac Orthodox bishop Mar Gregorios in the church in Niranam .
#Text=He received all the Holy Orders , from the tonsure to the episcopal consecration , and thereafter took the name Mar Dionysius . [ 3 ]

#Text=Syriac Orthodox and other critics of Mar Thoma VI saw this as his only ordination , while his supporters saw it as a " re-ordination " , but either way , it ended the controversy over the validity of his position . [ 4 ]
#Text=This done , Dionysius focused on his second primary aim of securing his place as the sole head of the Malankara Church , a measure opposed by some in the Syriac Orthodox hierarchy .
#Text=To this end , Dionysius appealed to both the Catholic Church and the British colonial government in India .
#Text=Several times he contacted the Catholic hierarchy , both locally and in Rome , seeking to have his church , with him as its designated head , brought into full communion .

#Text=This would have the double aim of solidifying his authority , and re-uniting all the Saint Thomas Christians , who had been split into Catholic and independent ( Malankara ) factions since the Coonan Cross Oath of 1653 .
#Text=His appeals were considered in Rome , where the Church was willing to grant him temporal but not spiritual authority over the Saint Thomas Christians .
#Text=In the end , however , no satisfactory deal was ever made and the factions remained separate . [ 5 ]
#Text=In 1771 , Mar Gregorios consecrated a second bishop , Kattumangatt , who took the name Mar Cyril ( Koorilose ) .
#Text=Dionysius saw Cyril as a threat to his authority , and appealed to the colonial authorities to suppress the rival bishop .
#Text=Cyril left for Thozhiyur , outside of the colonial jurisdiction , and established what would become an independent church .
#Text=This body is now known as the Malabar Independent Syrian Church . [ 6 ]
#Text=Subsequently , however , Gregorios and the other Syrian bishops died and were not replaced , leaving no further internal challengers to Dionysius . [ 7 ]
#Text=Invasion by Mysore
#Text=Mysore was a land locked kingdom .
#Text=Hyder Ali , ruler of this kingdom decided to invade Malabar to get access to the Arabian Sea .
#Text=He entered Malabar in 1781 and crushed the Nair soldiers .
#Text=After his death Tippu Sultan came to the throne .
#Text=During that period Christians were persecuted . [ 8 ] [ 9 ]
#Text=Bala Rama Varma was the ruler of Travancore at this time .
#Text=He was one of the least popular sovereigns whose reign was marked by unrest and various internal and external problems to the state . [ 10 ]
#Text=He became King at the young age of sixteen and came under the influence of a corrupt nobleman known as Jayanthan Sankaran Nampoothiri from Calicut .
#Text=One of the first acts of atrocities during his reign was the murder of Raja Kesavadas , [ 11 ] the existing Dewan of Travancore .
#Text=Sankaran Nampoothiri was then appointed as Dewan ( Prime minister ) with two other ministers . [ 12 ]

#Text=Using his influence , Mar Thoma VI was put in jail at Alleppy and was forced to conduct a service according to Catholic rites , but escaped during a rebellion in Travancore under Velu Thampi in 1799 . [ 13 ] [ 14 ]
#Text=Relations with the Church of England
#Text=Toward the end of Dionysius ' reign , Claudius Buchanan ( 1766 â€“ 1815 ) visited Kerala in 1806 , and arranged for the translation of the Bible into Malayalam .
#Text=Dionysius gave him the manuscript of the Bible written in the Syriac language .
#Text=This manuscript was later deposited in the public library of the University of Cambridge . [ 15 ]
#Text=During the visit Buchanan suggested the Malankara Church seek a close relationship with the Church of England .

#Text=Soon after his visit , Dionysius convened a meeting of church elders at Aarthattu , where he declared the Malankara Church would not accept Anglican doctrine , nor those of any other foreign church . [ 16 ]
#Text=Death and succession
#Text=Dionysius consecrated Pakalomattom Mathen Kathanar as his successor in 1796 at Chengannur church .
#Text=Dionysius died on 8 April 1808 at Niranam , and he was interred St. Mary 's Orthodox Cathedral , Puthencavu , with Mathen conducting the funeral service .
#Text=Mathen subsequently received his orders , taking the name Mar Thoma VII .
